intro: Pterocaulon xenicum, commonly known as the desert broom, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of North America. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-like fruits. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is well adapted to drought conditions. Its small, yellowish flowers bloom in spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Pterocaulon xenicum plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native habitat and is sometimes used in ecological restoration projects.
